title: Android 14 blocks all modification of system certificates, even as root?
dot:
digraph AndroidCA{rankdir=TB;node[shape=box, style=rounded, fontname="Arial", fontsize=12];edge[fontname="Arial", fontsize=10];subgraph cluster_android_history{label="Android History";style=filled;color=lightgrey;Android07[label="2007: Android Announced
'Open Platform', Full Developer Access"];Android07->Android16[label="Evolution"];Android16[label="2016: Android 7 (Nougat)
CA Split: OS Vendor vs. User"];Android16->Android23[label="Further Restrictions"];Android23[label="Current: Android 13
Root Access Allows CA Modification"];}subgraph cluster_android14{label="Android 14";style=filled;color=lightblue;Android14[label="Android 14 (Upside-Down Cake)
API v34"];Android14->CA_Restrictions[label="Tighter CA Restrictions"];CA_Restrictions[label="Impossible to Modify Trusted CAs
Even on Rooted Devices"];CA_Restrictions->APEX_Module[label="CA Management Moved to APEX Module"];APEX_Module[label="APEX Module: com.android.conscrypt
Certificates in /apex/...
Unmodifiable Even with Root"];APEX_Module->Workarounds[label="No Current Workarounds"];Workarounds[label="Challenges for Developers, Testers, Researchers"];}subgraph cluster_implications{label="Implications";style=filled;color=lightcoral;Implications[label="Loss of User Control
Impact on Debugging, Reverse Engineering"];Implications->Future_Concerns[label="Future APEX Modules May Further Limit User Control"];Future_Concerns[label="Potential Issues for Custom OS Releases, Magisk, etc."];}Android23->Android14[label="Next Step"];Workarounds->Implications[label="Consequences"];}
